speaker: Elena
text: The article's absolutely brutal. It says both Keynes and Hayek are not just dead, but fundamentally *wrong* for our current economic reality.

speaker: James
text: [sardonic] Harsh, but fair, I suppose. Though I'd argue their underlying principles still have merit, even if the prescriptions are outdated.

speaker: Elena
text: But that's the point, isn't it? Keynesian stimulus, Hayekian non-intervention... they were designed for a different world. We're applying 1930s solutions to 2020s problems.

speaker: James
text: True. The piece does make a compelling case that our structural landscape has shifted too dramatically.

speaker: Elena
text: Especially on demographics. Keynes's model relied on a growing young population to pay down debt. We have the opposite, especially in Europe.

speaker: James
text: You mean the 'economically crippled younger population' point? I did wince at that.

speaker: Elena
text: It's not hyperbole. Youth unemployment across the EU is over 25%. In Spain and Greece, it's above 50%. How exactly does a stimulus 'multiplier effect' work when half your young workforce is sitting idle?

speaker: James
text: [thoughtful] That's a strong counter to the traditional Keynesian argument. A shrinking tax base and a larger dependent population... it does create a debt burden that's almost impossible to pay down.

speaker: Elena
text: Exactly. They contribute little in taxes, but take significant amounts in education and support. It's a fundamental demographic mismatch.

speaker: James
text: I hadn't considered the scale of that demographic reversal quite so starkly. Keynes died at 62; that was old then, but young now.

speaker: Elena
text: Right. We're living longer, but not necessarily working longer, or having enough children to support it all. It's a looming fiscal catastrophe.

speaker: James
text: Which Hayek would have predicted, in a way. He'd have warned about the unsustainable growth fuelled by cheap credit and political expediency, though perhaps not the demographic angle directly.

speaker: Elena
text: But doing nothing, as Hayek's purest advocates suggest, isn't an option. The 2008 crash showed us that. A complete financial domino effect was a real possibility.

speaker: James
text: True. Hayek's strength was preventing bubbles, not cleaning up the mess after they burst. Politicians just want to be seen to 'do something', which means they'll always lean towards stimulus.

speaker: Elena
text: And the stimulus just leaks abroad! That's another huge problem the article highlights: the shift in global power and supply chains.

speaker: James
text: Go on.

speaker: Elena
text: A stimulus is supposed to boost domestic demand, creating domestic jobs. But if everyone's buying cheaper products from abroad, the cash just flows out of the economy, boosting *their* jobs.

speaker: James
text: [surprised] Wait, really? The article says stimulus money can actually make Western workers *less* confident, as they see jobs outsourced.

speaker: Elena
text: It does. And it makes perfect sense. If you get a stimulus cheque but your company just moved production to Vietnam, you're not exactly feeling secure. You save, not spend.

speaker: James
text: That's... actually devastating for the Keynesian model. A jobless recovery, fuelled by ever-increasing debt.

speaker: Elena
text: Precisely. The CBO predicts that by 2025, US interest payments, Medicare, Medicaid, and Social Security will consume 100% of federal tax income. That's 13 years away!

speaker: James
text: I remember that from our 'Crisis' article. A crisis of declining Western power and increasing internal obligations.

speaker: Elena
text: So, if both are wrong, what then? The article suggests some pretty radical solutions.

speaker: James
text: Managed inflation, for one. To reduce debt levels. It sounds risky, but the piece argues we understand the dynamics better than post-WW1 Germany.

speaker: Elena
text: It's better than default, which destabilises everything. Inflation makes the numbers add up, without the write-downs. Weâ€™ve written about 'Debt Jubilees' before.

speaker: James
text: Then there's the regional free trade idea. If you want to sell into a bloc, you build factories there. That brings the jobs home. I'm intrigued by that.

speaker: Elena
text: It forces companies to invest locally. Any stimulus then *actually* stimulates the domestic economy. China does it already, which we discussed in 'China Has Many Of The Characteristics Of An Emerging Colonial Power'.

speaker: James
text: [conceding] Okay, fine. I'll give you that one. In a world of fragmented supply chains and rising geopolitical tension, that kind of economic regionalisation makes more sense than pure globalism.

speaker: Elena
text: And the third point, about redirecting military spending. The US spends hundreds of billions on its Pacific fleet, ensuring trade routes with countries it has a massive trade deficit with.

speaker: James
text: That's... an astonishing sum. $400 billion deficit with East Asia alone. And maintaining a fleet for it.

speaker: Elena
text: It's economically irrational. The article suggests spending that money on domestic solar photovoltaics, generating free electricity and hundreds of thousands of jobs. Imagine that stimulus.

speaker: James
text: [dry] That would certainly be a rather direct application of 'buy local', wouldn't it? From global power projection to domestic energy independence. A profound shift.

speaker: Elena
text: It's about adapting. The 'renewables and battery revolution' article also makes this point. We have new tools, new challenges. We can't just keep trotting out Keynes and Hayek as gods.

speaker: James
text: They were brilliant for their time. But our time is defined by shrinking resources, an ageing population, and a radically different balance of power.

speaker: Elena
text: And if our leaders don't grasp that, then those CBO projections for 2025 will become a very painful reality. We need new thinking, not old dogma.
